required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Preformed Metal Crowns Placed Using the Hall Technique Versus the Conventional Restoration
clinical_study.official_title: The Preformed Metal Crowns Placed Using the Hall Technique Versus the Conventional Restoration: A 5-year Retro-prospective Clinical Study

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to compare the survival rate of the conventional restorations with the Hall Technique in carious primary molars.

primary_outcome.measure: The survival rate of Hall Technique and Compomer Restorations
primary_outcome.description: Successful: restoration satisfactory, no additional treatment required, no clinical sign and symptoms of pulpal pathology or tooth exfoliated, Minor failure: restoration wear/fracture/loss (restorable) or crown perforation, secondary caries or new caries, reversible pulpitis treated without requiring extraction or pulpotomy, Major failure: the tooth is broken down (unrestorable), inter-radicular radiolucency or internal root resorption, signs or symptoms of irreversible pulpitis requiring extraction or pulpotomy. The survival analysis: the restorations are assessed as successful or failure.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Preformed Metal Crowns using Hall Technique

intervention.intervention_name: Assessment of the stainless steel crown using the Hall Technique and Compomer Restoration on primary molars
intervention.description: Intra-oral clinical examination is performed and restorations are evaluated by the practitioner. Periapical radiography is taken according to national guidelines.
intervention.arm_group_label: Preformed Metal Crowns using Hall Technique

study_pop.textblock: patients aged 5-8 years treated with preformed metal crowns using Hall Technique and compomer restoration

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients aged five to eight years at the time of dental treatment,
- patients attending follow-up appointments
- patients with compomer restoration and Hall restoration in their teeth
- patients with matching the extent of caries in the two groups
Exclusion Criteria:
- patients not attending follow-up appointments
- patients without both treatment
